narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I got phenomenal writing practice, focused around historical writing about the Civil War and Reconstruction Era.

I have a much better understanding of the Civil War and Reconstruction era in American history. Like many American students, I had learned about the era in high school and in other education settings, but I found myself surprised and intrigued at every lecture. I also have a better understanding of how to write a history paper using primary and secondary sources.

I learned about the history of the American Civil War and Reconstruction through various primary and secondary sources and lectures.  I refined my writing skills through feedback from my TF.  I viewed history through a different lens.
This course taught me pretty much all there is to know about the Civil War and Reconstruction, including its causes, themes, and lasting impacts.
I learned so many things about the civil war and reconstruction era that I did not learn in high school. It was so applicable and explanatory for the moment we are in, and I really appreciated that.

This class of course provided an account of the history of, leading up to, and following the Civil War, but it also taught a lot about why we should still care about the Civil War in this day and age.
A knowledge of the Civil War and Reconstruction
Everything about the Civil War -- a lot was war history/strategy, and less focus was on the Reconstruction I felt.
I learned about the Civil War

I learned so much about the Civil War and Reconstruction that I hadn't learned in high school history classes. Prof Shinn did a great job of making the history accessible and demonstrating the dynamics/events/etc he was talking about with primary sources and direct examples that kept it interesting. It definitely added to my knowledge of the Civil War itself and of the overall history of slavery, Jim Crow, and white supremacy in the US. Definitely a great class to take to get an in-depth but also relatively comprehensive course on the Civil War.
I learned how to write a good paper, how to think about historical sources, how to consider all people involved, and a deep knowledge of the time period within the course.
I learned a lot about social movements during the mid-1800s and how those fueled the Civil War and shaped post-war racial realities.

I learned a lot about what led to the Civil War, the political stakes, the cultural aspect of the war, the leading figures, and the aftermath + impact on the country. Probably the course in which I felt I learned the most this semester!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: So much reading, a lot of it seemed unnecessary. But the lectures were very interesting and engaging.
Strengths of the course were definitely the reading list and how the readings corresponded directly with the weekly readings. Sometimes readings were lengthy but always manageable.

This class is phenomenal. Prof Shinn is an excellent lecturer, and my TA (Anna) was outstanding. The feedback I got on all my assignments was exceptionally useful. Quality of lecture/lecture content is superb.

I thought Professor Shinn was a fantastic lecturer. I always looked forward to class, even in a Zoom semester. I also thought our teaching fellows did a great job of both reviewing concepts and exploring ideas more deeply than would be possible in lecture. I would personally have enjoyed exploring more of the reconstruction era and the late nineteenth centurywe spent a good amount of time on the war (and rightfully so) but I found the later portion especially intriguing and far less widely known. The readings were always interesting, and the workload was very manageable.

Strengths - well-organized, clear feedback, comprehensive coverage of the timeline, approachable office hours
Weaknesses - too fast at times, inconsistent amount of reading
This was a fantastic class that anyone interested in US history should take.
I think the hardest part of the course for me was the amount of reading assigned. But the lectures themselves were incredibly well laid-out, clear, and informative.
Great introduction to a lot of the prevailing thought surrounding race and slavery in the mid-19th century.

Strengths: Prof. Shinn is a really nice guy, and the lectures were very straightforward. Assignments were also super fair.
Weaknesses: can't think of any.
It was a great course
It was a great course.

Strengths: the depth and breadth of the readings. I really got a clear sense of the big picture and equally enjoyed our deeper dives into the lives of everyday citizens in our readings.

Weaknesses: I think that the chronological order of the material was useful in most cases to organize when/how things occurred, but I wonder if some themes would be clearer with a little more thematic grouping.
This course was very engaging and had great discussion sections!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Having the courses recorded for review later was very helpful, even if I would have vastly preferred to take the course in person. Zoom sections are always a bit awkward, but our teaching fellows did as well as they could with a group that wasn't always eager to answer.
Professor Shinn met his students exactly where they were and was very accommodating via Zoom.  I only wish we would've had more opportunity to speak after class with him.
The online lecture format worked very well for the class.
It was great
Lecture over Zoom was good overall but probably could have been more interesting/engaging in person, but compared to other virtual classes it definitely was a relatively interesting Zoom lecture.
I hope this question never has to be answered again and we can just be in person. Though, it is nice to have the material recorded to be able to rewatch certain things for clarity.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, but with a grain a salt. A great credit/d option, as the material is interesting and something that everyone should probably have a better understanding of. That being said, some of the TAs grade a lot harder than others and there is a ton of reading (similar to an English class where you read a book a week, sometimes more).

If you are looking for a general history of the American Civil War and the aftermath I would take this class. The focus of the class is more on political movements and motivations behind the war opposed to the memorization of various battles. Highlights a less drawn out narrative of the force of enslaved peoples in northern victory.
Yes, you will learn a lot and the teaching is excellent.

Yes! This is a great history course for major and nonmajors. For majors, it's a great exploration of a pivotal moment in American history that you can then apply to every other history course you take about the region or the concepts (so much of the material is still terrifyingly relevant). For non-majors, this is a very approachable introduction to the discipline where you can learn interesting content, try out a few papers, and read interesting readings with a great professor.

I would absolutely recommend this class to another student.  It is great for non-humanities majors because it covers a topic that most Americans are familiar with.  As a history major, I also felt that it was worth taking because I learned a lot of information that I had never been exposed to before.
Yes. This course is a very thorough overview of the Civil War. I would recommend it to any student who is interested in American history.
Yes, it is super interesting and I really enjoyed it.
Yes! This course is so full of information and so engaging. Professor Shinn is an interesting communicator, and the application to today is so important. Take the class!
I would absolutely recommend the course. It did exactly what I expected of it: it was an excellent introduction to Civil War History.
Yes! The material is extremely interesting and easily accessible.
I definitely would! Especially if you want to have a good understanding of the Civil War (obviously) and get a better picture of earlier U.S. history.
Yes, it was a great course.
Yes! I'm really glad I know everything I came away from this course with in terms of understanding the history of the Civil War accurately.
Yes 100% - I really enjoyed Professor Shinn's teaching style and the readings were interesting. A great gateway course for anyone interested in African American Studies, American Studies or History.
I would definitely recommend to someone who wants to delve into the Civil War and Reconstruction. This knowledge is very useful to understand the current state of US politics and culture.
Yes! I think the history learned is something every American should know. It's really important in understanding a lot of modern discourse on race. Would highly recommend.
Yes, it's a good hums credit for a stem major. It's no gut though so be prepared.

Yes! This is a great foundational course in the Civil War and Reconstruction. It teaches you everything you need to know about the era-- not in tremendous depth, but it doesn't need to. Professor Shinn is great and gives very engaging lectures. The TFs were also very prepared. Assignment-wise, it was not strenuous, just 2 short, topical papers and a take-home final exam. I'd highly recommend this class to anyone interested in the CIvil War and following events.
I would recommend this course to anyone who has any interest in learning more about the Civil War period.
I would only recommend this  course if students had a particular TF in mind. I did not overly enjoy lecture, but the TFs really make or break this class.

This was my favorite class this past semester! I found the material fascinating and actually looked forward to discussion section. I learned so much and felt I had a better understanding of modern day U.S. after taking this class.
